001package imagingbook.lib.util.progress;
002
003import imagingbook.lib.filter.GenericFilter;
004import imagingbook.lib.util.progress.ij.ProgressBarMonitor;
005
006/**
007 * This class represents a "progress monitor". This is a simple
008 * {@link Thread} that queries the attached target task 
009 * (implementing {@link ProgressReporter}) and calls its 
010 * {@link #handleProgress(double, long)} method at regular intervals.
011 * 
012 * {@link ProgressMonitor} implements the {@link AutoCloseable} and thus can
013 * (and should) be used in a try-with-resources context, e.g.,
014 * <pre>
015 * ProgressReporter task = ....; // the task to be monitored
016 * try (ProgressMonitor m = new MyProgressMonitor(task)) {
017 *     // run task ...
018 * }</pre>
019 * Otherwise, if not used in a auto-start/close mode, the methods {@link #start()} 
020 * and {@link #close()} should be used to "manually" start and terminate
021 * monitoring.
022 * See {@link GenericFilter} and {@link ProgressBarMonitor} for an example.
023 */
024public abstract class ProgressMonitor extends Thread implements AutoCloseable {
025        
026        public static int DefaultWaitTime = 250; // ms
027        
028        private int waitTime = DefaultWaitTime;
029        private final ProgressReporter target;
030
031        private boolean running;
032        private long startTime, endTime;
033        
034        /**
035         * Constructor, starts monitoring immediately.
036         * The target object's {@link ProgressReporter#getProgress()}
037         * method is called it regular intervals.
038         * 
039         * @param target the object (task) to be monitored
040         */
041        public ProgressMonitor(ProgressReporter target) {
042                this(target, true);
043        }
044        
045        /**
046         * Constructor, optionally starts monitoring immediately or waits
047         * for its {@link #start()} method to be called (which starts the 
048         * associated thread).
049         * The target object's {@link ProgressReporter#getProgress()}
050         * method is called it regular intervals.
051         * 
052         * @param target the object (task) to be monitored
053         * @param autoStart starts immediately if true
054         */
055        public ProgressMonitor(ProgressReporter target, boolean autoStart) {
056                if (target == null)
057                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("null target instance!");
058                this.target = target;
059                if (autoStart) {
060                        start();
061                }
062        }
063        
064        /**
065         * The time interval between progress queries can be set with this method.
066         * See also {@link #DefaultWaitTime}.
067         * 
068         * @param waitTime the time interval (in milliseconds)
069         */
070        public void setWaitTime(int waitTime) {
071                this.waitTime = waitTime;
072        }
073        
074        /**
075         * Abstract method to be implemented by concrete sub-classes.
076         * It is called by the {@link ProgressMonitor} thread in regular intervals.
077         * Current progress data are passed.
078         * It is up to the implementation what action should be performed,
079         * e.g., display the current progress graphically 
080         * (see e.g. {@link ProgressBarMonitor}).
081         * 
082         * @param progress the current progress value [0,1)
083         * @param elapsedNanoTime the time elapsed since the progress monitor was started (in nanoseconds)
084         */
085        public abstract void handleProgress(double progress, long elapsedNanoTime);
086        
087        // --------------------------------------------------------
088
089        @Override
090        public void run() {
091                handleProgress(0, 0);
092                this.startTime = System.nanoTime();
093                running = true;
094                do {
095                        try {
096                                Thread.sleep(waitTime);
097                        } catch (InterruptedException e) {break;}
098                        handleProgress(target.getProgress(), System.nanoTime() - startTime);
099                } while(running);
100                this.endTime = System.nanoTime();
101        }
102        
103        @Override
104        public void close() {
105                running = false;
106        this.interrupt();
107        }
108        
109        // --------------------------------------------------------
110        
111        /**
112         * Returns the time elapsed since monitoring started (in seconds).
113         * @return the elapsed time in seconds
114         */
115        public double getElapsedTime() { // result is in seconds
116                if (running) {
117                        return  (System.nanoTime() - startTime) / 1E9d;
118                }
119                else {
120                        return (endTime - startTime) / 1E9d;
121                }
122        }
123
124}
